key_title: Key to the species of Millotia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Short, P.S.
source.title: Millotia
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Short, P.S. (1999). Millotia. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Corolla-lobes 3 or 4; anthers not prominently exserted at anthesis
Corolla-lobes 4 or 5; anthers prominently exserted at anthesis
Involucral bracts covered in cottony hairs (if glandular hairs present thheen obscured by cottony hairs); pappus of 12–25 plumose, subequal bristles c. two-thirds to as long as corolla tube

Involucral bracts with prominent stalked, glandular hairs (cottony hairs present but not obscuring glandular hairs); pappus of 17–30 barbellate bristles c. equal to or just exceeding corolla, rarely of unequal length and only c. two-thirds the length of the corolla, or reduced to a ring of scales

Involucral bracts covered in stalked glandular hairs (cottony hairs sometimes present but not obscuring the surface of the bract); major axes ascending to erect; apex of fruit somewhat to strongly dilated, the junction between beak and corolla-tube distinct

Involucral bracts densely covered in cottony hairs which may obscure the surface of the bract, stalked glandular hairs also present; major axes prostrate; apex of fruit not obviously dilated and the junction between the beak and corolla-tube indistinct
